lead_paragraph: FOR almost 65 years, Smokey Bear has been reminding Americans, “Only you can prevent forest fires” (and, more recently, wildfires). abstract: David J. Kahn’s timely tribute.
snippet: David J. Kahn’s timely tribute.
lead_paragraph: David J. Kahn is the master of special event puzzles. When the particular event is unexpected, he has to do his magic on a compressed time schedule. The entire crossword production staff, including editors, test solvers and fact checkers, has to scramble. It’s worth it, though. A tribute puzzle is a rare honor, but the sudden passing of 10/25 Down deserves to be noted. The quicker the better, of course, and amazingly this puzzle appears in print just six days after we first heard the sad news.

headline.main: Bit of Wordplay

abstract: Karl Malden died on Wednesday at the age of 97, according to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Mr. Malden, a veteran actor who was famous for his roles in films like “Baby Doll,” “On the Waterfront,” “A Streetcar Named Desire,” “One-Eyed Jacks,” and “Patton” among many others, was a president of the academy for three terms, beginning with his first, in 1990.
snippet: Karl Malden died on Wednesday at the age of 97, according to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Mr. Malden, a veteran actor who was famous for his roles in films like “Baby Doll,” “On the Waterfront,” “A Streetcar Named Desire,” “One...
lead_paragraph: Karl Malden died on Wednesday at the age of 97, according to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Mr. Malden, a veteran actor who was famous for his roles in films like “Baby Doll,” “On the Waterfront,” “A Streetcar Named Desire,” “One-Eyed Jacks” and “Patton,” among many others, was a president of the academy for three terms; his first began in 1990. He became a familiar figure on television thanks to his role in “The Streets of San Francisco” series and others. Born in Chicago in 1912, Mr. Malden was then named Mladen Sekulovich.

headline.main: Karl Malden, Screen and TV Great, Dies at 97

abstract: Although they’re meant to be helpful, Microsoft Word 2007’s ScreenTips can also get in the way.

lead_paragraph: Although they’re meant to be helpful, Microsoft Word 2007’s ScreenTips (those explanatory panels that pop up when you rest the mouse cursor over onscreen icons and commands) can also get in the way, especially if you know the program and don’t need them. To turn off the tips, click on the round Office button in the top corner of the screen and choose Word Options at the bottom of the box. Click on Popular in the left pane and in the ScreenTips Style area, choose “Don’t show ScreenTips” from the pop-up menu. Click O.K. to close the box and get back to Word.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Turning Off Microsoft Tips

snippet: A recently published study finds that women are more loyal than men to individual service providers, but men exhibit more loyalty to groups and companies.
lead_paragraph: A paper recently published in the Journal of Marketing reassesses the conventional wisdom that women are more loyal customers than men. Jobs, because we already know everything we need to know to make an informed decision about Apple’s stock. Mr. Jobs has had cancer, a disease where, as Mr. Carr puts it, “the prognosis is always unknowable.” Then, a few months ago, while taking a leave of absence related to his health, Mr. Jobs had a liver transplant. Mr. Carr also points out — touché — that for all the talk about Mr. Jobs’s indispensability, Apple’s stock rose $50 a share while he was gone.

abstract: The potential perils of Washington’s staggering deficits are known, but trying to overcome them during a recession carries its own risks.
snippet: The potential perils of Washington’s staggering deficits are known, but trying to overcome them during a recession carries its own risks.
lead_paragraph: No one argues that the staggering deficits run up by the American government in a bid to rescue the economy are desirable, healthy or even sustainable  not if the national debt continues to swell at its current pace. But considerable debate centers on when and how vigorously to start easing off Washington’s borrowing habit, with substantial risks at both extremes.

headline.main: Staggering Budget Gap and a Reluctance to Fill It
headline.print_headline: A Sinking Sound, And a Test of Nerve

abstract: A new report on who’s leaving their jobs, and who’s getting hired.
snippet: A new report on who’s leaving their jobs, and who’s getting hired.
lead_paragraph: The Bureau of Labor Statistics today released its Job Openings and Labor Turnover report for May. As you might expect, the hiring rate (calculated by dividing the number of new job hires by total nonfarm employment and multiplying that quotient by 100) fell again. At 3.0 percent, it is at its lowest point since the series began in December 2000.

headline.main: Hiring and Job Separations Down

lead_paragraph: Want quick access to My Computer, My Documents or any folder on your Windows XP or Vista system? You can add it to your taskbar by right-clicking on the taskbar and selecting Toolbars from the menu. Choose New Toolbar from the menu and navigate to the folder you want to use and click Select Folder or O.K. When you click the taskbar icon for the folder you added, a pop-up menu lets you browse its contents and open files right there.

snippet: It remains unclear how much money is at stake and what the money would be used for.
lead_paragraph: The Obama Administration is considering diverting some of the $700 billion in bank bailout money to the Small Business Administration’s 7(a) loan program, according to a report published Friday evening by The Washington Post. In the 7(a) program, the S.B.A. offers banks a guaranty — temporarily raised to 90 percent in the 2009 stimulus package — for loans to small firms. Borrowers get long-term loans with low monthly payments; the proceeds can be used for most business purposes.

headline.main: Obama Administration Said to Be Weighing TARP Money for S.B.A.

abstract: A former Morgan Stanley broker, Darin DeMizio, was sentenced to 38 months for his part in a stock loan scheme that generated $1.7 million in kickbacks to his family.
snippet: A former Morgan Stanley broker, Darin DeMizio, was sentenced to 38 months for his part in a stock loan scheme that generated $1.7 million in kickbacks to his family.
lead_paragraph: A former Morgan Stanley broker, Darin DeMizio, was sentenced to 38 months for his part in a stock loan scheme that generated $1.7 million in kickbacks to his family. Mr. DeMizio, 46, left, a former supervisor at Morgan Stanley’s domestic securities lending desk in New York, was convicted in March of securities and wire fraud. Judge John Gleeson of United States District Court said he would decide later how much restitution Mr. DeMizio must pay. Prosecutors said Mr. DeMizio paid his brother and father, supposedly for helping find the stocks. Prosecutors said at a weeklong trial in March that the men did little work for the fees.

headline.main: Former Broker Gets 38 Months in Stock Scheme
headline.print_headline: Former Broker Gets 38 Months In Stock Scheme

abstract: AFTRA leaders discuss the state of the entertainment industy.
snippet: AFTRA leaders discuss the state of the entertainment industy.

abstract: The International Accounting Standards Board made a bold move to simplify accounting for financial instruments.
snippet: The International Accounting Standards Board made a bold move to simplify accounting for financial instruments.
lead_paragraph: Anyone foolish enough — as I was — to try to read the accounting rules on financial instruments knows that they are mind-numbingly complex. I’ve sort of taken for granted that all this complexity was necessary, and maybe it is. But as we have seen in recent months,the widely varying rules have meant that one instrument would be accounted for quite differently from a seemingly similar one. Or it could be different from an identical one, based on the intent of the institution owning it.

headline.main: Keep It Simple

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company has sold WQXR-FM, the classical music station that it has owned since 1944, in a deal that shifts the station’s call numbers (96.3) to Univision’s Spanish-language station and moves WQXR to Univision’s old position at 105.9, where it will be operated by WNYC as a listener-sponsored station. The good news, for classical music fans, is that the station will remain New York’s only station dedicated solely to classical music — although it will have a weaker signal and less prestigious position on the FM dial.

headline.main: New York Times Sells WQXR-FM, but It Will Remain a Classical Music Station

lead_paragraph: If you have any museum visits planned for summer vacation, a quick visit to the institution’s Web site before you go can land you free MP3 audio tours or podcasts on the exhibits you plan to see. For example, the National Gallery of Art in Washington has audio and video podcasts (www.nga.gov/podcasts/index.shtm). Sir John Soane’s Museum in London has a full audio tour (introduced by the actor Stephen Fry) of the collection, available at www.soane.org/audio.html. Apple has audio tours from several museums posted at www.apple.com/ipod/ipodtours.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: An Audio Tour for Your Visit to the Museum

abstract: Belated government attention for a plan to turn overextended homeowners into renters, and a look at the rocky start for Bank of America’s ownership of Merrill Lynch.
snippet: Belated government attention for a plan to turn overextended homeowners into renters, and a look at the rocky start for Bank of America’s ownership of Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: No, that is the not the subject of my column this week. But I was so doggone excited to hear that the Obama administration is finally — finally! — considering an idea that was first broached last fall by Dan Alpert of Westwood Capital on this very blog that I couldn’t let the moment pass without a cheer or two. The idea is to turn at-risk homeowners into renters, at least temporarily. During a Senate Banking Committee hearing earlier this week on foreclosures, a Treasury official said, “It is certainly an idea we are thinking about.” It’s about time.

headline.main: Up With Renters!

abstract: Golden Gate Capital, a private equity firm, won the bankruptcy auction for Eddie Bauer Holdings, the outdoor clothing chain, with a $286 million bid.
snippet: Golden Gate Capital, a private equity firm, won the bankruptcy auction for Eddie Bauer Holdings, the outdoor clothing chain, with a $286 million bid.
lead_paragraph: Golden Gate Capital, a private equity firm, won the bankruptcy auction for Eddie Bauer Holdings, the outdoor clothing chain, with a $286 million bid and a plan to keep most of its stores open. Golden Gate also plans to keep most of the retailer’s outlets and employees, Eddie Bauer said Friday. Golden Gate’s offer will be presented for court approval Wednesday, the company said. Eddie Bauer attracted bidders as varied as the Iconix Brand Group of New York, the owner of the Rocawear clothing brand, and the liquidators Hilco Consumer Capital and the Gordon Brothers Group, said David Pollack, a bankruptcy lawyer. Eddie Bauer, which opened its first sporting-goods store in Seattle in 1920, has about 370 stores in the United States and Canada.

headline.main: Eddie Bauer Chooses Buyer in Bankruptcy Auction
headline.print_headline: Eddie Bauer Chooses Buyer In Bankruptcy Auction

abstract: Accenture, the technology consulting firm, agreed to buy a Nokia business that advises and provides services for cellphone makers using the Symbian operating system, the companies said Friday.
snippet: Accenture, the technology consulting firm, agreed to buy a Nokia business that advises and provides services for cellphone makers using the Symbian operating system, the companies said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Accenture, the technology consulting firm, agreed to buy a Nokia business that advises and provides services for cellphone makers using the Symbian operating system, the companies said Friday. The unit helps phone manufacturers make the operating system work with their products, and aids chip makers and carriers. Terms were not disclosed. The deal adds 165 employees to Accenture’s organization and lets the company expand a business that provides consulting services related to mobile operating systems. Symbian is the world’s most popular software running more advanced cellphones, and is used on more than 250 million handsets.

headline.main: Accenture Acquires a Phone Concern From Nokia
headline.print_headline: Accenture Acquires a Phone Concern From Nokia

lead_paragraph: President Obama said Friday he would nominate Robert Hormats, a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, to a top economic position at the State Department. Mr. Hormats, 66, will be under secretary of state for economic, energy and agricultural affairs. He was deputy trade representative from 1979 through 1981 and held other posts at the State Department throughout his career. Hillary Rodham Clinton, the secretary of state, said in a speech on Wednesday that she hoped to make economic policy and trade a larger part of United States diplomacy.

headline.main: Goldman Executive Named as Obama Adviser

abstract: UPDATE: Sony is emerging as the likeliest winner in bidding for Michael Jackson rehearsal footage.
snippet: UPDATE: Sony is emerging as the likeliest winner in bidding for Michael Jackson rehearsal footage.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY UPDATE: Both Sony and AEG have remained mum on the prospects for a Michael Jackson concert film based on the rehearsal videos from Mr. Jackson’s planned tour. But people who were briefed on a film rights auction that has been under way since last week are predicting that Sony will wind up with the movie at a price of more than $60 million, even though a parallel televised tribute concert will steal some of the movie’s thunder. One such person says it quickly became apparent to studios like Universal, Paramount and Fox that Sony was the only viable bidder because the company already controlled crucial rights through its music venture. The inside betting says the movie will be on the Sony schedule for October — others had been pushing for an earlier date, to catch the Jackson wave while it is still breaking. But, again, no deal has yet been announced.

headline.main: Sony Appears Likeliest Buyer of Michael Jackson Rehearsal Footage

abstract: If you buy enough votes — in a corporate election, that is — you have to disclose.
snippet: If you buy enough votes — in a corporate election, that is — you have to disclose.
lead_paragraph: One of the opportunities opened up by the wonderful world of derivatives is vote-buying in corporate elections. To do that, you buy the stock, with the vote, prior to a contested shareholder vote. At the same time, you enter into what are called “equity swaps” with a friendly broker, who for a fee agrees to reimburse any losses you might suffer from owning the shares, and to receive any profits.

headline.main: Vote-Buying, Corporate Style

According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour reality show delivered an average of 8 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. Although slightly more viewers tuned in to CBS’s repeats of “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (9.2 million) and “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.4 million), ABC did manage to lead every hour of the night in the 18-to-49 set.

abstract: Many small companies are going out of business needlessly because they do not know what they do not know. They need more counseling and less talk of “cleansing.”

lead_paragraph: I recently read an article in The New York Times headlined “Family Businesses Are Reeling In Recession.” The article includes a graph from a report issued by the National Federation of Independent Business that shows a drop in small business sales of 10 to 33 percent. That is consistent with what I have heard in talking to 20 or 30 business owners that I know. The article talks about H.A. Peterson and Sons, a company that was founded as Harold A. Peterson Steeplejack in 1926 and that sells and services flagpoles and flags. By the ’70s, the company was pretty much out of the steeple business and focused on flagpoles. At its peak, in the ’80s and ’90s, it had six employees and annual revenue of $500,000. It is now down to just Scott Peterson and his wife.

headline.main: Too Small to Fail?

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company reported a second-quarter net income of $39.1 million, up from $21.1 million in the period a year ago, as another steep drop in advertising revenue was largely offset by aggressive cost-cutting. Thursday’s results marked a return to profitability after a first quarter loss.

headline.main: New York Times Company Returns to Profitability in Second Quarter

abstract: General Motors says its talks over Opel’s rescue will focus on the consortium of auto parts maker Magna International and Sberbank, as well as RHJ International, The Associated Press reported, while talks with Beijing Automotive Industry Corp. have ceased.
snippet: General Motors says its talks over Opel’s rescue will focus on the consortium of auto parts maker Magna International and Sberbank, as well as RHJ International, The Associated Press reported, while talks with Beijing Automotive Industry Corp. hav...
lead_paragraph: General Motors said Thursday that its talks over Opel’s rescue would focus on the consortium of the Canadian auto parts maker Magna International and the Russian lender Sberbank and on RHJ International, a Belgium-based investor. But no mention was made of Beijing Automotive Industry Corporation, a third bidder, suggesting talks with the Chinese company may have ended.

headline.main: G.M.’s Opel Update Omits Chinese Bidder

abstract: Congress faces the difficult task of reconciling two visions of how the government should harness the power of small firms to innovate. The bills pit bootstrapped companies against venture-backed companies.

lead_paragraph: With health care reform and economic recovery sucking up so much of what little oxygen circulates in Washington, you’ll have to forgive The Agenda for only now turning to the Small Business Innovation Research program, which is set to expire on July 31 unless Congress acts to reauthorize it.

headline.main: How Should Government Spur Small-Business Innovation?

abstract: To reduce grogginess, the Sleeptracker watch tries to gently wake you up with its alarm-window concept, but its wake-me-at-the-perfect-time system won’t work for everyone.

It's a $400 bedside alarm clock that comes with a wireless headband that monitors your brain waves. In the morning, the clock's screen shows you a graph of your night's sleep cycles (light sleep, deep sleep, dream sleep, waking).

abstract: Advocacy groups ask Google to commit to privacy guarantees for its book search service before a court review of a legal settlement.
snippet: Advocacy groups ask Google to commit to privacy guarantees for its book search service before a court review of a legal settlement.
lead_paragraph: Three advocacy groups have asked Google to commit to protect the privacy of readers in its book search service, which is poised for a major expansion under a pending class-action settlement. The groups, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the American Civil Liberties Union and the Samuelson Law, Technology and Public Policy Clinic at the University of California, Berkeley, have asked Google to limit the data it collects about users’ reading habits, to commit to protect reader records by handing them over only in response to subpoenas or court orders, and to put into effect measures giving users control of their data.

headline.main: Advocates Ask Google for Privacy Guarantees in Online Library

abstract: It is the hot new thing on Wall Street, a way for traders to master the stock market, peek at investors’ orders and, critics say, subtly manipulate share prices. It is called high-frequency trading — and it is one of the most talked-about forces in the markets.
snippet: It is the hot new thing on Wall Street, a way for traders to master the stock market, peek at investors’ orders and, critics say, subtly manipulate share prices. It is called high-frequency trading — and it is one of the most talked-about forces i...
lead_paragraph: It is the hot new thing on Wall Street, a way for a handful of traders to master the stock market, peek at investors’ orders and, critics say, even subtly manipulate share prices. It is called high-frequency trading — and it is suddenly one of the most talked-about and mysterious forces in the markets, writes Charles Duhigg in The New York Times.

Keith Lee, the chief executive of Booyah, a start-up based in Palo Alto, Calif., is hoping to tap into that gear lust as a way to get players hooked on the company’s new iPhone game. But to succeed in the game, players will have to put their phones down once in a while.

Those much-cited dentists were saying not that sugar-free was good, of course, as much as preferable to regular gum.

headline.main: Selling Gum With Health Claims

abstract: Going on vacation? Don’t forget a list of your medications, and take remedies for common hazards like ticks.
snippet: Going on vacation? Don’t forget a list of your medications, and take remedies for common hazards like ticks.
lead_paragraph: JUST one hour into the start of my recent Disneyland vacation, I tripped on a tree root by the hotel pool and jammed my toe. The pain was intense. My husband kindly looked up nearby orthopedists on the Internet and suggested I go see one. Instead I called the number on the back of my insurance card (yes, I’m frugal) and was transferred to a nurse who said, based on my symptoms, my toe was probably not broken, and that ice and ibuprofen might be enough.

headline.main: My Vacation? Oh, Just Relaxing at the E.R.
headline.print_headline: My Vacation? Oh, Just Relaxing at the E.R.

abstract: Sniping between tabloids over Mets controversy? There’s a stunner.
snippet: Sniping between tabloids over Mets controversy? There’s a stunner.
lead_paragraph: When the Mets attacked The New York Daily News beat reporter Adam Rubin after he wrote a story that contributed to the firing of Tony Bernazard, the vice president of player personnel, other reporters on the beat were supportive for the most part, suggesting that the Mets’ general manager, Omar Minaya, was just trying to change the subject. But on Wednesday, the chronic war between the New York tabloids seemed to supersede any efforts at professional solidarity.

headline.main: The End of Tabloid Detente?

abstract: Some companies pay straight commission. Others pay only salary. And many others do some combination. I have been to seminars, talked to consultants, and read articles on the subject. Everyone who has an opinion is sure it’s right.
snippet: Some companies pay straight commission. Others pay only salary. And many others do some combination. I have been to seminars, talked to consultants, and read articles on the subject. Everyone who has an opinion is sure it’s right.
lead_paragraph: I have five outside salespeople who call on designers, corporations, professional firms, and institutions for Chicago Art Source. For years I have paid a base salary and commission. This is a sales job that requires some art and design background, as well as the ability to find new customers since most companies eventually run out of walls to hang things on. It is particularly difficult because most organizations buy art only when moving or re-decorating.

headline.main: What’s The Best Way to Reward Sales People?
